questions.text: A patient suffering from leprosy is prescribed a Jaipur foot prosthesis in the rehabilitation center. Which of the following statements is true about this prosthesis?

choices.text: Inversion and eversion are not possible
Possible to walk on uneven ground

questions.solution:
It is possible to walk on uneven grounds with Jaipur foot prosthesis as subtalar movements (inversion and eversion) are present.

Different types of foot prostheses are:

  • Jaipur foot
  • Solid ankle cushion heel (SACH)
  • Stationary attachment flexible endoskeleton (SAFE), similar to Jaipur foot.
Prosthesis  SACH Jaipur foot

Mobility Restricted Allowed
Dorsiflexion Absent Present

Inversion/Eversion

Absent

 Present

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the instrument shown in the image?

choices.text: It is used to irrigate the maxillary sinus
Direction of the tip is indicated by the hook outside
It can be used for irrigation in Caldwell Luc  operation

questions.solution:
The instrument is Rose's sinus douching cannula and it is not used for trephination (also known as trepanning or burr holing).

Rose’s sinus douching cannula is used in the irrigation of maxillary sinus, which should already have a nasoantral window due to intranasal antrostomy or Caldwell–Luc operation.

The direction of the tip is indicated by the hook outside.

Note:

Trephination (also known as trepanning or burr holing) is a surgical intervention where a hole is drilled, incised, or scraped into the skull using simple surgical tools. Trephination of frontal sinus is done for acute frontal sinusitis if there is persistence or exacerbation of pain or pyrexia in spite of medical treatment for 48 h or if the lid swelling is increasing and threatening orbital cellulitis.

questions.text: Which among the following is false regarding the insertion of the tube shown below?

choices.text: Length to be inserted should be measured from angle of mouth to ear to xiphisternum
Severe midface trauma is a contraindication
Patient should be seated in upright position
Can be used for identification of cancer cells

questions.solution:
The given image is that of a nasogastric tube/ Ryles tube. The commonly used method to determine the length of a nasogastric tube is the NEX method: the tip of the nose to ear to xiphisternum.

NEX method:

  • Nose–Ear–Xiphisternum 
  • The tube length should be estimated before insertion.
  • Place the exit port of the tube at the tip of the nose. Extend tube to the earlobe, and then to xiphisternum.

Indications:

  • Aspiration of gastric fluid
  • Identification of esophagus and stomach on chest X-ray
  • Administration of radiographic contrast to GIT
  • Gastric lavage cytology to identify cancer cells in gastric cancer patients
  • Gastric decompression
  • Feeding
  • Administration of medication
  • Bowel irrigation

Inserting a Ryle's tube:

Ryle's tube is inserted in the sitting position with the neck slightly flexed.

Confirmation of the correct position is done by the following:

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • X-ray chest
  • Colorimetric capnography

Approximate length: 120-125 cm

The markings indicate the traversing of the tube through various parts of the GIT:

  1. 40 cm: Cardia of the stomach
  2. 50 cm: Body of the stomach
  3. 60 cm: Pylorus
  4. 70 cm: Duodenum

Contraindications:

Absolute:

  • Severe midface trauma
  • Recent nasal surgery

Relative:

  • Coagulation abnormality
  • Esophageal varices (NG tube can be used for lower grade varices)
  • Recent banding of esophageal varices
  • Anastomoses in stomach and esophagus

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm.

questions.text: The device shown in the given image is used for the monitoring of:
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a pulse oximeter. Pulse oximetry is used for monitoring pulse rate and oxygen saturation of a patient.

A small sensor is placed on the finger, toe, earlobe, or another convenient place.

The relative absorption of light by oxyhemoglobin (HbO) and deoxyhemoglobin is assessed by measuring the amount of red and infrared light emerging from tissues traversed by light rays and processed by the device, producing an oxygen saturation level.

Pulse oximetry does not measure the absolute content or the partial pressures of oxygen or carbon dioxide.

questions.solution:
The image shows an anomaloscope, which is used for testing colour vision.

An anomaloscope is based on a colour match. On one side, you have a yellow color which can be adjusted in brightness. The other side consists of a red and a green light whereas the proportion of mixture is variable.

Jackson’s cross cylinder (flip-cross technique); used to refine the power and axis of the cylindrical lens is shown below.

Maddox rod consists of parallel red or colorless cylinders stacked together. Maddox rod test is a macular function test used to measure the degree of heterotropia or heterophoria in cases of torsional diplopia.

Intraocular pressure is measured by tonometry.

questions.text: The apparatus shown below is used to estimate:
questions.solution:
The given image is that of Horrock’s apparatus which is used to determine the chlorine demand of water.

It consists of:

  • 6 white cups of 200 ml each
  • 1 black cup with a circular mark inside
  • 2 metal spoons -each holds 2g of bleaching powder
  • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
  • Two droppers
  • Starch-iodide indicator solution

The dose of bleaching powder required for disinfection of water can be calculated using this apparatus.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the suture material shown in the image?

choices.text: Can be used for securing drains externally
Can be used with vascular prosthesis

questions.solution:
The given image is that of silk suture material. Silk is black colored, multifilament, natural, braided, and non-absorbable suture material derived from the cocoon of the silkworm larva.

Silk is not suitable for use with a vascular prosthesis or in tissues requiring prolonged approximation under stress. It is unsuitable for routine skin closure as there is an increased risk of infection and tissue reaction. It can be used for securing drains externally. Fibrous encapsulation of the suture occurs in 1 to 2 weeks and it is absorbed slowly over 1 to 2 years.

Vicryl is violet colored absorbable suture material:

Plain catgut is yellowish absorbable suture material.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is used for _______
questions.solution:
The image shows Hertel's exophthalmometer used to measure proptosis.

Exophthalmometry: measures protrusion of the apex of the cornea from the outer orbital margin (with the eyes looking straight ahead).

An absolute protrusion of >20 mm or a difference of >2 mm between the two eyes is labeled as proptosis.

Instruments used to measure proptosis:

  • Luedde exophthalmometer
  • Hertel’s exophthalmometer: The most common instrument used. Its advantage is that it measures both eyes simultaneously.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient is being taken up for a cervical discectomy. The surgeon had planned a posterior approach that required the patient to lie in a prone position under anesthesia. What is the advantage of the armored endotracheal tube required for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The advantage of an armored endotracheal tube is less kinking.

Armored tubes (a.k.a. reinforced tubes, flexo-metallic tubes) are flexible, spiral wound tubes that are reinforced with metal coils. This minimizes kinking of the tube.

They are useful in surgeries of head and neck and surgeries performed with the patient in the prone position.

Armored or Flexo-metallic endotracheal tube:

Other specialized endotracheal tubes include:

  • Microlaryngeal tubes: have smaller internal diameters and longer lengths which makes them useful for laryngeal surgeries. 
  • Metal tubes: are LASER resistant and are used for laser airway surgery to reduce fire hazards.
  • Double-lumen tubes: have two lumens (tracheal and bronchial) to facilitate lung isolation and one-lung ventilation in thoracic surgeries.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The given image is that of an enucleation spoon. This is identified by the central cleavage that engages the optic nerve in enucleation.

 

Other options:

Option A- Evisceration spatula consists of a small but stout rectangular blade with a slightly convex surface and blunt edges attached to a handle. It is used to separate out the uveal tissue from the sclera during evisceration operation.

 

Option C- Chalazion clamp consists of two limbs like forceps, which can be clamped with the help of a screw. The tip of one limb is flattened in the
form of a round disc while the tip of the other arm has a small circular ring. It is used to fix the chalazion and achieve hemostasis during the incision and curettage operation.

 

Option D- Bone punch consists of a stout spring handle and two blades attached at a right angle. It is used to enlarge the bony opening during
dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) operation by punching the bone from the margins of the opening.

Holding period 160 degree Celsius for 2 hours

questions.solution:
The given image is that of a hot air oven. Spores of Clostridium tetani act as a control in a hot air oven.

Hot air oven:

  • It is a method of sterilization by dry heat.
  • Holding period of 160°C for 2 hours is used to sterilize glassware, swabs, glass syringes, scalpel, forceps, scissors.
  • Cutting instruments in ophthalmic surgery – 2 hours at 150°C.
  • Spores of Clostridium tetani act as a control.

Autoclave machine:

  • Sterilization by moist heat.
  • High penetrative power
  • Temperature - 121°C for 15 min
  • Spores of Bacillus stearothermophilus acts as a control.

Autoclave machine is shown above.

questions.text: Which among the following is used in the study of corneal endothelium?
questions.solution:
Specular microscopy is the study of the corneal endothelium under very high magnification (100 times greater than slit-lamp biomicroscopy).

The endothelium can be analyzed for cellular size, shape, density, and distribution. The healthy endothelial cell is a regular hexagon, and the normal cell density in a young adult is about 3000 cells/mm2.

A keratometer (ophthalmometer) measures the curvature of the anterior surface of the cornea at two points about 1.25 mm on either side of its center.

A pachymeter measures the corneal thickness.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding the instrument shown below.

choices.text: It is a blunt-type spinal needle.
The incidence of post-dural puncture headache is high.
It is technically more challenging to use.

questions.solution:
The image shown is the Quincke needle that is used in spinal anesthesia. Its use is associated with a high incidence of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) due to CSF leak.

The Quincke needle is a cutting needle with an end injection.

Types of spinal needles:

Cutting needle

Non-cutting (splitting, pencil point, blunt) needle

Cut the dura

Split the dura

Hence, higher incidence of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) due to CSF leak

Hence, lower incidence of PDPH

Technically less challenging as loss of resistance is well appreciated during lumbar puncture

Technically more challenging as loss of resistance is not well appreciated

E.g. Quincke-Babcock, Pitkin

E.g. Whitacre, Sprotte

The illustration given below shows the tips of various spinal needles.

The image given below shows a combined spinal epidural (CSE) needle.

Related Pearl: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

Related Pearl: Factors That Can Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Age: Younger, more frequent
  • Sex: Females > males
  • Needle size: Larger > smaller
  • Needle bevel: Less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis Orienting a needle bevel parallel with the axis of the spine, such that the longitudinal fibers of the dura would more likely be separated than cut, results in a lower incidence of postspinal puncture headache
  • Pregnancy: More when pregnant
  • Dural punctures: More with multiple punctures

Factors That Do Not Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Insertion and use of catheters for continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Timing of ambulation

questions.text: The instrument shown below is used for liver biopsy. Which of the following is the most common complication associated with the procedure?
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a liver biopsy needle. It has a bifid needle. The most common complication of liver biopsy is pain.

Pain is most common at the biopsy site or right shoulder (often indicates subcapsular hematoma). In most patients pain is relieved by analgesics.

Liver biopsy:

  • Indications
    • Evaluation of abnormal LFT
    • Suspected hepatic neoplasm
    • Diagnosis of cholestatic liver disease
    • Evaluation of infiltrative or granulomatous disease
    • Following a case of liver transplantation
    • To evaluate unexplained jaundice or suspected drug reaction
  • Contraindications
    • Increased prothrombin time (PT), INR> 1.6
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • Ascites
    • Difficult body habitus
    • Suspected hemangioma
    • Suspected echinococcal infection
    • Uncooperative patient
  • Complications
    • Pain (most common)
    • Bleeding: Intraperitoneal, intrahepatic, subcapsular, hemobilia
    • Bile peritonitis
    • Bacteremia
    • Sepsis and abscess formation
    • Pneumothorax
    • Haemothorax
    • Arteriovenous fistula

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument shown below?

choices.text: If used early reduces cardiac output
It is to be removed 48 hours after birth
Delayed clamping should be avoided in Rh- pregnancy
Increases iron stores in the baby

questions.solution:
The given image shows an umbilical cord clamp. It should be kept in place until it falls off with the detached stump of the umbilical cord.

It is made of plastic and supplied in a sterile pack. It occludes the umbilical vessels effectively. In preterm infants, delayed clamping may improve transitional circulation, establish better red blood cell volume, reduce the need for blood transfusion and reduce the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis and intraventricular haemorrhage. It should be delayed by 30-60 seconds after birth.

Other options:

Option A: If performed early reduces cardiac output owing to reduced preload to the left ventricle whereas if performed late permits sufficient aeration of the lung and improved / smoother transitioning to a better cardiac output.

Option C: Early cord clamping is advised in Rh-negative pregnancy, babies with asphyxia, or infants of diabetic mothers. Early clamping can also reduce the need for phototherapy due to hyperbilirubinemia. 

Option D: Delayed umbilical cord clamping in term infants will increase haemoglobin levels at birth and improve iron stores for the first few months. This may have a favourable effect on developmental outcomes.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is used for:

choices.text: Delivery of occipitotransverse position in platypelloid pelvis
Delivery of after coming head in breech delivery
Outlet forceps used to provide traction force

questions.solution:
The image shows Wrigley's forceps, which is an outlet forceps used to provide traction force.

 Wrigley's forceps are used exclusively in outlet forceps operations for the extraction of the head. It is used to provide traction force. The instrument is light and short due to a reduction in the length of the shanks and handles. It has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve. Outlet forceps are used when:

  • The fetal scalp is visible without separating the labia
  • The fetal skull has reached the pelvic floor, at or on the perineum
  • The sagittal suture is in the anteroposterior diameter or right or left occiput anterior or posterior position (rotation does not exceed 45°)

Other options:

Option A: Kielland forceps are used in correcting asynctilism.

Option B: Barton forceps are used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.

Option C: Piper forceps have a distinct perineal curve and allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: What is the most effective circuit for anaesthesia under spontaneous breathing?
questions.solution:
The most effective circuit for anesthesia under spontaneous breathing is Mapleson A or Magill's circuit.

When the Mapleson A circuit is used for spontaneous ventilation, the fresh gas flow rate of the circuit is closest to the physiological minute ventilation of the patient. Hence it is preferred over other circuits.

 

Related Pearl: Mapleson Classification

Mapleson circuit   Other name  Fresh gas flow rate
Spontaneous ventilation  Controlled ventilation
A Magills 1 minute ventilation (MV) i.e. 80 ml/kg/min Very high and difficult to predict
B - 2-3× (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
C Water’s to and fro 2-3 × (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
D Bain circuit 2-3 × (MV) 1-2 × (MV)
E Ayre’s t-piece 2-3 × (MV) 3 × (MV)
F Jackson rees modification 2-3 × (MV) 2 × (MV)

 

Note:

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB (A Dog Can Bite - Usually a spontaneous event)

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A (Dead Babies can't assist - controlled)

questions.text: Currently, the kata thermometer is used to measure only:
questions.solution:
A kata thermometer was originally devised to measure the cooling power of air but is now only used to measure low air velocities.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument shown below?

choices.text: It is the safest in procedures close to vital structures
It can be used for coagulation
It can be used for cutting
There is more thermal dissipation of current

questions.solution:
From the single-tipped electrode in the cautery image shown below, we can identify the instrument is a unipolar cautery. The false statement is option A. Due to a high thermal spread in unipolar cautery, it is not the safest instrument during procedures close to vital structures. The vitals structures are at risk of thermal injury with this instrument. 

Electrosurgery is the use of high-frequency currents to cut or coagulate tissue during surgery. It can be performed using:

  • Monopolar or unipolar cautery: consists of a single electrode tip
  • Bipolar cautery: consists of two electrode tips in the form of scissors, graspers, etc. 

Other options

Option B: It is true that unipolar cautery can be used for coagulating tissue. The two main settings in unipolar and bipolar cautery are:

  • Coagulation mode: Blue button in the image above.
  • Cutting mode: Yellow button in the image above

In the coagulation mode, a high-voltage current is produced that spreads over a greater surface area. This helps to produce a dehydration effect on the tissues and is very useful when trying to stop the bleeding from nicked vessels during surgery. 

Option C: It is true, as mentioned above that unipolar cautery can be used for cutting tissue. Cutting mode produces a low voltage current that acts on a smaller surface area. This makes it more effective in heating the tissue than in the coagulation mode. The thermal spread will also be less than the coagulation mode, making it safer. 

Option D: It is true that monopolar cautery produces more thermal dissipation of current.

questions.text: What is the following instrument used to measure?
questions.solution:
The image given is that of an Assmann psychrometer which is used to measure humidity.

They consists of two thermometers each inside a double tube for minimizing radiative heating.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

questions.text: Identify the condenser in the following image.
questions.solution:
This is a modern compound microscope, and the condenser is located below the stage.

The purpose of the condenser lens is to focus the light from the illuminator onto the specimen. Microscopes with a stage condenser lens render a sharper image than those with no condenser lens.

The simple microscope was invented first by Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, the father of microscopy and microbiology. It uses 1 lens for magnification. The compound microscope, introduced by Hans and Zacharias Janssen uses 2 lenses, an objective lens and an eyepiece, to provide better magnification power than the simple microscope.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image performed in a patient prior to undergoing cataract surgery:
questions.solution:
The given image shows A-scan ultrasonography. It is used for determining the axial length and can be acquired by direct contact (as shown in the image) or by using a water bath over the eye (immersion ultrasonography).

The sound beam must be aligned with the visual axis for maximal precision. Each reflecting surface is represented by a spike on the oscilloscope monitor.

The most widely used formula for intraocular lens power calculation is the Sanders-Retzlaff-Kraff formula, given by

E = A - 2.5L - 0.9K

The value of L, which is the axial length of the eyeball is calculated using the A-scan ultrasonographic biometry

E is the emmetropic power designated for the eye 

  • A is a constant which is specific for each lens type.
  • L is the axial length of the eyeball in mm determined using the A-scan ultrasonography.
  • K is the average corneal curvature, which is determined by keratometry.

questions.text: The instrument shown below is placed in front of the left eye with cylinders in the horizontal direction. The patient is asked to fixate on a point source of light. The patient sees a vertical line and a white light. The white light is seen on the right side of the line. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
The above instrument is a Maddox rod. It consists of a series of fused cylindrical red glass rods. It is used to measure the degree of heterophoria or heterotropia in cases of torsional diplopia. The given test result is suggestive of esophoria.

Maddox Rod Test:

  • It involves the use of a Maddox rod and the Maddox tangent scale.
  • It uses a specially constructed device, consisting of a series of parallel cylinders, that converts a point source of light into a line image.
  • A patient is asked to fix on a point light 6 meters away.
  • The optical properties of the cylinders cause the streak of light to be situated 90° to the orientation of the parallel cylinders.
  • Because fusion is precluded by the Maddox rod, heterophorias, and heterotopias cannot be differentiated.
  • The Maddox rod can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclo-deviations.

Interpretation of the Test:

  • To test for horizontal deviations, the Maddox rod is placed in front of one eye (for this example, the left eye) with the cylinders in the horizontal direction.
  • The patient fixates a point source of light and then sees a vertical line with the left eye and white light with the right eye.
  • If the light superimposes the line, orthophoria is present.
  • If the light is on the left side of the line, it is an exo-deviation; and if the light was on the right side of the line, an esodeviation would be present.

Orthophoria: Perfect ocular alignment in the absence of any stimulus for fusion

Hypophoria: Downward imbalance

Hyperphoria: Upward imbalance

Exophoria: Outward imbalance

Esophoria: Small inward imbalance

In the following image, the interpretation of the result is based on how the patient visualizes it. It would appear to be crossed to the patient. Pictorial representation of the eyes are as seen by the examiner. Imagine you are looking through a Maddox rod over your left and right eyes while interpreting the images.

questions.text: Identify the laryngoscopic blade given in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given image is that of the Macintosh laryngoscopic blade, an instrument that allows for laryngeal examination and tracheal intubation. It is the most commonly used laryngoscopic blade for endotracheal intubation in adults.

Laryngoscopic blades can be:

  • Curved  - Macintosh
  • Straight - Miller

Miller is the most commonly used blade in infants.

Advantage of curved blade:

  • Greater room available for the passage for an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth

The tip of the curved Macintosh blade is placed in the vallecula after the tongue is slid leftward and anteriorly. The laryngoscope handle is lifted in a forward and upward direction (stretching the hyoepiglottic ligament). This causes the epiglottis to move upward, eventually exposing the vocal cords.
